Expectation1: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation1: A client has an inquiry about a specific line item on their most recent invoice.
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: During a street demonstration, someone urges them to step past a barricade onto restricted city property.
Story:
I was on my lunch break, phone pressed to my ear, trying to explain a confusing invoice line to a frustrated client. As an accountant, I knew I had to be clear and professional, even as the noise from the street demonstration outside my office window grew louder. The client’s voice was tense, demanding answers, and I felt the pressure to resolve the issue quickly and accurately.

Just then, I stepped outside to get better reception and found myself swept into the crowd. Someone beside me, a fellow protester, urged me to step past a police barricade onto restricted city property, insisting it was the only way to make our voices heard. As a citizen, I knew I should respect the law and public property, but the energy of the crowd was infectious, and the cause felt urgent.

My phone buzzed again—the client was waiting. I stood at the edge of the barricade, torn between my duty to my client and my responsibility as a law-abiding citizen, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
